content:
GeoCoordinate Class

Definition

Represents a geographical location that is determined by latitude and longitude coordinates. May also include altitude, accuracy, speed, and course information.

In this Article

public class GeoCoordinate : IEquatable<System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate>
Inheritance
Object
GeoCoordinate

Inherited Members

Equals(Object, Object)
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object, Object)

Constructors

GeoCoordinate()

Initializes a new instance of GeoCoordinate that has no data fields set.

public GeoCoordinate ();

Remarks

All data fields are set to NaN. The new instance of GeoCoordinate is equivalent to Unknown.

This constructor should be used for serialization.

GeoCoordinate(Double, Double)

Initializes a new instance of the GeoCoordinate class from latitude and longitude data.

public GeoCoordinate (double latitude, double longitude);
Parameters
latitude
Double

The latitude of the location. May range from -90.0 to 90.0.

longitude
Double

The longitude of the location. May range from -180.0 to 180.0.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

Latitude or longitude is out of range.

Remarks

The latitude and longitude values must correspond to an actual location on the globe.

GeoCoordinate(Double, Double, Double)

Initializes a new instance of the GeoCoordinate class from latitude, longitude, and altitude data.

public GeoCoordinate (double latitude, double longitude, double altitude);
Parameters
latitude
Double

Latitude. May range from -90.0 to 90.0.

longitude
Double

Longitude. May range from -180.0 to 180.0

altitude
Double

The altitude in meters. May be negative, 0, positive, or Double, if unknown.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

latitude, longitude, or altitude is out of range.

Remarks

The latitude and longitude values must correspond to an actual location on the globe.

GeoCoordinate(Double, Double, Double, Double, Double, Double, Double)

Initializes a new instance of the GeoCoordinate class from latitude, longitude, altitude, horizontal accuracy, vertical accuracy, speed, and course.

public GeoCoordinate (double latitude, double longitude, double altitude, double horizontalAccuracy, double verticalAccuracy, double speed, double course);
Parameters
latitude
Double

The latitude of the location. May range from -90.0 to 90.0.

longitude
Double

The longitude of the location. May range from -180.0 to 180.0.

altitude
Double

The altitude in meters. May be negative, 0, positive, or Double, if unknown.

horizontalAccuracy
Double

The accuracy of the latitude and longitude coordinates, in meters. Must be greater than or equal to 0. If a value of 0 is supplied to this constructor, the stem.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate.HorizontalAccuracy* property will be set to NaN.

verticalAccuracy
Double

The accuracy of the altitude, in meters. Must be greater than or equal to 0. If a value of 0 is supplied to this constructor, the stem.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate.VerticalAccuracy* property will be set to NaN.

speed
Double

The speed measured in meters per second. May be negative, 0, positive, or Double, if unknown. A negative speed can indicate moving in reverse.

course
Double

The direction of travel, rather than orientation. This parameter is measured in degrees relative to true north. Must range from 0 to 360.0, or be Double.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

latitude, longitude, horizontalAccuracy, verticalAccuracy, or course is out of range.

Fields

Unknown

Represents a GeoCoordinate object that has unknown latitude and longitude fields.

public static readonly System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate Unknown;

Remarks

The IsUnknown property can be used to verify whether a GeoCoordinate contains no data.

Properties

Altitude

Gets the altitude of the GeoCoordinate, in meters.

public double Altitude { get; set; }
Value
Double

The altitude, in meters.

Remarks

The altitude is given relative to sea level.

Course

Gets or sets the heading in degrees, relative to true north.

public double Course { get; set; }
Value
Double

The heading in degrees, relative to true north.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

Course is set outside the valid range.

Remarks

The valid range includes values from 0.0 to 360.0, and Double.NaN if the heading is not defined.

HorizontalAccuracy

Gets or sets the accuracy of the latitude and longitude that is given by the GeoCoordinate, in meters.

public double HorizontalAccuracy { get; set; }
Value
Double

The accuracy of the latitude and longitude, in meters.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

HorizontalAccuracy is set outside the valid range.

Remarks

The accuracy can be considered the radius of certainty of the latitude and longitude data. A circular area that is formed with the accuracy as the radius and the latitude and longitude coordinates as the center contains the actual location.

IsUnknown

Gets a value that indicates whether the GeoCoordinate does not contain latitude or longitude data.

public bool IsUnknown { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the GeoCoordinate does not contain latitude or longitude data; otherwise, false.

Remarks

A GeoCoordinate that does not contain latitude or longitude data is equal to Unknown.

Latitude

Gets or sets the latitude of the GeoCoordinate.

public double Latitude { get; set; }
Value
Double

Latitude of the location.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

Latitude is set outside the valid range.

Remarks

Latitude can range from -90.0 to 90.0. Latitude is measured in degrees north or south from the equator. Positive values are north of the equator and negative values are south of the equator.

Longitude

Gets or sets the longitude of the GeoCoordinate.

public double Longitude { get; set; }
Value
Double

The longitude.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

Longitude is set outside the valid range.

Remarks

The longitude can range from -180.0 to 180.0. Longitude is measured in degrees east or west of the prime meridian. Negative values are west of the prime meridian, and positive values are east of the prime meridian.

Speed

Gets or sets the speed in meters per second.

public double Speed { get; set; }
Value
Double

The speed in meters per second. The speed must be greater than or equal to zero, or Double.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

Speed is set outside the valid range.

VerticalAccuracy

Gets or sets the accuracy of the altitude given by the GeoCoordinate, in meters.

public double VerticalAccuracy { get; set; }
Value
Double

The accuracy of the altitude, in meters.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

VerticalAccuracy is set outside the valid range.

Methods

Equals(GeoCoordinate)

Determines if the GeoCoordinate object is equivalent to the parameter, based solely on latitude and longitude.

public bool Equals (System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate other);
Parameters
other
GeoCoordinate

The GeoCoordinate object to compare to the calling object.

Returns
Boolean

true if the GeoCoordinate objects are equal; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Equivalent GeoCoordinate objects have the same Latitude and Longitude properties. The Altitude, HorizontalAccuracy, and VerticalAccuracy properties are not used to determine equivalency.

Equals(Object)

Determines if a specified GeoCoordinate is equal to the current GeoCoordinate, based solely on latitude and longitude.

public override bool Equals (object obj);
Parameters
obj
Object

The object to compare the GeoCoordinate to.

Returns
Boolean

true, if the GeoCoordinate objects are equal; otherwise,false.

Remarks

Equivalent GeoCoordinate objects have the same Latitude and Longitude properties. The Altitude, HorizontalAccuracy, and VerticalAccuracy properties are not used to determine equivalency.

GetDistanceTo(GeoCoordinate)

Returns the distance between the latitude and longitude coordinates that are specified by this GeoCoordinate and another specified GeoCoordinate.

public double GetDistanceTo (System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate other);
Parameters
other
GeoCoordinate

The GeoCoordinate for the location to calculate the distance to.

Returns
Double

The distance between the two coordinates, in meters.

Remarks

The Haversine formula is used to calculate the distance. The Haversine formula accounts for the curvature of the earth, but assumes a spherical earth rather than an ellipsoid. For long distances, the Haversine formula introduces an error of less than 0.1 percent.

Altitude is not used to calculate the distance.

GetHashCode()

Serves as a hash function for the GeoCoordinate.

public override int GetHashCode ();
Returns
Int32

A hash code for the current GeoCoordinate.

Remarks

GeoCoordinate objects that are equivalent have the same hash code. Equivalent GeoCoordinate objects have the same Latitude and Longitude properties. The Altitude, HorizontalAccuracy, and VerticalAccuracy properties are not used to determine equivalency.

ToString()

Returns a string that contains the latitude and longitude.

public override string ToString ();
Returns
String

A string that contains the latitude and longitude, separated by a comma.

Remarks

The string representation returned by this method is intended only for debugging use. This method does not return any locale-specific formatting for latitude and longitude.

Operators

op_Equality(GeoCoordinate, GeoCoordinate)

Determines whether two GeoCoordinate objects refer to the same location.

public static bool op_Equality (System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate left, System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate right);
Parameters
left
GeoCoordinate

The first GeoCoordinate to compare.

right
GeoCoordinate

The second GeoCoordinate to compare.

Returns
Boolean

true, if the GeoCoordinate objects are determined to be equivalent; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Equivalent GeoCoordinate objects have the same Latitude and Longitude properties. The Altitude, HorizontalAccuracy, and VerticalAccuracy properties are not used to determine equivalency.

op_Inequality(GeoCoordinate, GeoCoordinate)

Determines whether two GeoCoordinate objects correspond to different locations.

public static bool op_Inequality (System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate left, System.Device.Location.GeoCoordinate right);
Parameters
left
GeoCoordinate

The first GeoCoordinate to compare.

right
GeoCoordinate

The second GeoCoordinate to compare.

Returns
Boolean

true, if the GeoCoordinate objects are determined to be different; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Equivalent GeoCoordinate objects have the same Latitude and Longitude properties. The Altitude, HorizontalAccuracy, and VerticalAccuracy properties are not used to determine equivalency.
